Melanic.name: Melanic
Melanic.description: (from Greek melas, black): having a melanic horizon starting ? 30 cm from the soil surface (in Andosols only) (2: except Endo-).

Lithic.name: Lithic
Lithic.description: (from Greek lithos, stone): having continuous rock or technic hard material starting ? 10 cm from the soil surface (in Leptosols only).

Glacic.name: Glacic
Glacic.description: (from Latin glacies, ice): having a layer ? 30 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, containing ? 75% ice (by volume) (2).

Differentic.name: Differentic
Differentic.description: (from Latin differentia, difference): having an argic or natric horizon that meets diagnostic criterion 2a for the respective horizon.

Densic.name: Densic
Densic.description: (from Latin densus, dense): having natural or artificial compaction ? 100 cm from the soil surface to the extent that roots cannot penetrate, or can only penetrate it with severe difficulty (2).

Ferritic.name: Ferritic
Ferritic.description: (from Latin ferrum, iron): having a layer ? 30 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, with Fedith in the fine earth fraction of ? 10% and not forming part of a petroplinthic, pisoplinthic or plinthic horizon (2).

Muusic.name: Muusic
Muusic.description: (from Sakha muus, ice): having ice that is directly overlain by organic material (in Histosols only) (1: Epi- and Endo- only).

Calcaric.name: Calcaric
Calcaric.description: (from Latin calcarius, containing lime): having calcaric material throughout between 20 and 100 cm from the soil surface, or between 20 cm and continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer, whichever is shallower; and not having a calcic or a petrocalcic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (4).

Gleyic.name: Gleyic
Gleyic.description: (from Russian gley, mucky soil mass): having a layer ? 25 cm thick, and starting ? 75 cm from the mineral soil surface, that has gleyic properties throughout and reducing conditions in some parts of every sublayer (2).

Technic.name: Technic
Technic.description: (from Greek technae, art): having ? 10% (by volume, weighted average) artefacts in the upper 100 cm from the soil surface or to continuous rock or a cemented or indurated layer, whichever is shallower; or having a layer ? 10 cm thick, and starting ? 90 cm from the soil surface, with ? 50% (by volume, weighted average) artefacts (5 or 2: Epi- and Endo- only).

Anthraquic.name: Anthraquic
Anthraquic.description: (from Greek anthropos, human being, and Latin aqua, water): having an anthraquic horizon and no hydragric horizon.

Hydrophobic.name: Hydrophobic
Hydrophobic.description: (from Greek hydor, water, and phobos, fear): water-repellent, i.e. water stands on a dry soil surface for ? 60 seconds (in Arenosols only).

Protic.name: Protic
Protic.description: (from Greek protou, before): showing no soil horizon development, with the exception of a cryic horizon, which may be present.

Hypertechnic.name: Hypertechnic
Hypertechnic.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having ? 20% (by volume, weighted average) artefacts in the upper 100 cm from the soil surface or to continuous rock or a cemented or indurated layer, whichever is shallower (5).

Aridic.name: Aridic
Aridic.description: (from Latin aridus, dry): having aridic properties without takyric or yermic properties.

Infraandic.name: Infraandic
Infraandic.description: (from Latin infra, below, and Japanese an, dark, and do, soil): having a layer ? 15 cm thick, that underlies a soil classified with preference according to the �Rules for classifying soils� (Chapter 2.5) and that meets diagnostic criteria 1 and 3 of the andic properties and fails diagnostic criterion 2.

Protostagnic.name: Protostagnic
Protostagnic.description: (from Greek protou, before): having a layer ? 25 cm thick, and starting ? 75 cm from the mineral soil surface, that does not form part of a hydragric horizon and that has: � stagnic properties in which the area of reductimorphic colours plus the area of oximorphic colours is ? 10% and < 25% of the layer's total area, and � reducing conditions for some time during the year in the major part of the layer's volume that has the reductimorphic colours (2).

Carbonic.name: Carbonic
Carbonic.description: (from Latin carbo, coal): having a layer ? 10 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, with ? 20% (by mass) organic carbon that meets the diagnostic criteria of artefacts (2).

Hemic.name: Hemic
Hemic.description: (from Greek hemisys, half): having, after rubbing, less than twothirds and one-sixth or more (by volume) of the organic material consisting of recognizable plant tissue within 100 cm of the soil surface (in Histosols only).

Plinthofractic.name: Plinthofractic
Plinthofractic.description: (from Greek plinthos, brick): having a layer ? 10 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, consisting of a broken petroplinthic horizon, the remnants of which: � occupy a volume of ? 40%, and � have an average horizontal length of < 10 cm and/or occupy a volume < 80% (2).

Limnic.name: Limnic
Limnic.description: (from Greek limnae, pool): having one or more layers with limnic material with a combined thickness of ? 10 cm within ? 50 cm of the soil surface.

Arenic.name: Arenic
Arenic.description: (from Latin arena, sand): having a texture class of sand or loamy sand in a layer ? 30 cm thick, within ? 100 cm of the mineral soil surface or in the major part between the mineral soil surface and continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting < 60 cm from the mineral soil surface starting < 60 cm from the mineral soil surface (2; no subqualifier if continuous rock or technic hard material starts < 60 cm from the mineral soil surface).

Ornithic.name: Ornithic
Ornithic.description: (from Greek ornithos, bird): having a layer ? 15 cm thick, with ornithogenic material starting ? 50 cm from the soil surface (2).

Hyperartefactic.name: Hyperartefactic
Hyperartefactic.description: (from Greek hyper, over, and Latin ars, art, and factus, made): having ? 50% (by volume, weighted average) artefacts within 100 cm of the soil surface or to continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer, whichever is shallower (in Technosols only).

Relictigleyic.name: Relictigleyic
Relictigleyic.description: (from Latin relictus, left back): having a layer ? 25 cm thick, and starting ? 75 cm from the mineral soil surface, that has gleyic properties throughout and no reducing conditions (2).

Nechic.name: Nechic
Nechic.description: (from Amharic nech, white): having uncoated mineral grains of silt or sand size in a darker matrix somewhere within ? 5 cm of the mineral soil surface.

Hypereutric.name: Hypereutric
Hypereutric.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having: � in Histosols, a pHwater ? 5.5 throughout in the organic material within 100 cm of the soil surface and ? 6.5 in some layer with organic material within ? 100 cm of the soil surface, � in other soils, an effective base saturation [exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na) / exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na + Al); exchangeable bases by 1 M NH4OAc (pH 7), exchangeable Al by 1 M KCl (unbuffered)] of ? 50% throughout between 20 and 100 cm from the mineral soil surface, and ? 80% in some layer between 20 and 100 cm from the mineral soil surface.

Leptic.name: Leptic
Leptic.description: (from Greek leptos, thin): having continuous rock or technic hard material starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (1: Epi- and Endo- only).

Sodic.name: Sodic
Sodic.description: (from Spanish soda, gaseous water): having a layer ? 20 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, that has ? 15% Na plus Mg and ? 6% Na on the exchange complex; and not having a natric horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Acric.name: Acric
Acric.description: (from Latin acer, sharp): having an argic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface and having a CEC (by 1 M NH4OAc, pH 7) of < 24 cmolc kg-1 clay in some part ? 50 cm below its upper limit; and having an effective base saturation [exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na) / exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na + Al); exchangeable bases by 1 M NH4OAc (pH 7), exchangeable Al by 1 M KCl (unbuffered)] of < 50% in half or more of the part between 50 and 100 cm from the mineral soil surface or in the lower half of the mineral soil above continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting ? 100 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is shallower (2).

Somerimollic.name: Somerimollic
Somerimollic.description: (from Spanish somero, superficial): having a mollic horizon, < 20 cm thick.

Gibbsic.name: Gibbsic
Gibbsic.description: (from the mineral gibbsite, named after the US mineralogist George Gibbs): having a layer ? 30 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, containing ? 25% gibbsite in the fine earth fraction (2).

Technoskeletic.name: Technoskeletic
Technoskeletic.description: (from Greek technae, art): having ? 40% (by volume) coarse fragments, that meet the criteria of artefacts, averaged over a depth of 100 cm from the soil surface or to continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer, whichever is shallower (5).

Puffic.name: Puffic
Puffic.description: (from English to puff): having a crust pushed up by salt crystals (in Solonchaks only).

Hyperthionic.name: Hyperthionic
Hyperthionic.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having a thionic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface and having a pH (1:1 in water) < 3.5 (2).

Stagnic.name: Stagnic
Stagnic.description: (from Latin stagnare, to stagnate): having a layer ? 25 cm thick, and starting ? 75 cm from the mineral soil surface, that does not form part of a hydragric horizon and that has: � stagnic properties in which the area of reductimorphic colours plus the area of oximorphic colours is ? 25% of the layer's total area, and � reducing conditions for some time during the year in the major part of the layer's volume that has the reductimorphic colours (2).

Immissic.name: Immissic
Immissic.description: (from Latin immissus, sent inside): having at the soil surface a layer ? 10 cm thick, with ? 20% (by mass) recently sedimented dust, soot or ash that meets the criteria of artefacts (2: Ano- and Panto- only).

Akroskeletic.name: Akroskeletic
Akroskeletic.description: (from Greek akra, top): having ? 40% of the soil surface covered by fragments that have a greatest dimension ? 6 cm (stones, boulders or large boulders).

Tephric.name: Tephric
Tephric.description: (from Greek tephra, pile ash): having tephric material, starting ? 50 cm from the soil surface, that is � ? 30 cm thick, or � ? 10 cm thick and directly overlying continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer (2).

Anthroumbric.name: Anthroumbric
Anthroumbric.description: (from Greek anthropos, human being): having an umbric horizon and anthric properties (2: Ano- and Panto- only).

Yermic.name: Yermic
Yermic.description: (from Spanish yermo, desert): having yermic properties, including a desert pavement.

Sombric.name: Sombric
Sombric.description: (from French sombre, shade): having a sombric horizon starting ? 150 cm from the soil surface (2).

Gypsic.name: Gypsic
Gypsic.description: (from Greek gypsos, gypsum): having a gypsic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Pellic.name: Pellic
Pellic.description: (from Greek pellos, dusty): having in the upper 30 cm of the soil a Munsell colour value of ? 3 and a chroma of ? 2, both moist (in Vertisols only).

Hyperhydragric.name: Hyperhydragric
Hyperhydragric.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having an anthraquic horizon and a directly underlying hydragric horizon with a combined thickness of ? 100 cm.

Hypergypsic.name: Hypergypsic
Hypergypsic.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having a gypsic horizon with a gypsum content in the fine earth fraction of ? 50% (by mass) and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Oligeoeutric.name: Oligeoeutric
Oligeoeutric.description: (from Greek oligos, few): having an effective base saturation [exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na) / exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na + Al); exchangeable bases by 1 M NH4OAc (pH 7), exchangeable Al by 1 M KCl (unbuffered)] of ? 50% and a sum of exchangeable bases of < 5 cmolc kg-1 clay: * in the major part between 20 and 100 cm from the mineral soil surface, or * in the major part between 20 cm from the mineral soil surface and continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting > 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, or * in a layer ? 5 cm thick, directly above continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting ? 25 cm from the mineral soil surface (3).

Protoargic.name: Protoargic
Protoargic.description: (from Greek protou, before, and Latin argilla, white clay): having an absolute clay increase of ? 4% from one layer to the directly underlying layer within ? 100 cm of the mineral soil surface (in Arenosols only) (1).

Terric.name: Terric
Terric.description: (from Latin terra, earth): having a terric horizon, and � in Anthrosols, not having a hortic, irragric, plaggic or pretic horizon with a thickness of ? 50 cm (2: Panto- only), and � in other soils, not having a hortic, irragric, plaggic or pretic horizon.

Calcifractic.name: Calcifractic
Calcifractic.description: (from Latin calx, lime): having a layer ? 10 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, consisting of a broken petrocalcic horizon, the remnants of which: � occupy a volume of ? 40%, and � have an average horizontal length of < 10 cm and/or occupy a volume of < 80% (2).

Areninovic.name: Areninovic
Areninovic.description: (from Latin arena, sand): having a layer, ? 5 cm and < 50 cm thick, with a texture class of sand or loamy sand in its major part, overlying a buried soil that is classified with preference according to the �Rules for classifying soils� (Chapter 2.5).

Argisodic.name: Argisodic
Argisodic.description: (from Latin argilla, white clay): having an argic horizon, starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, that has ? 15% Na plus Mg and ? 6% Na on the exchange complex throughout the argic horizon or within its upper 40 cm, whichever is thinner (2).

Pisoplinthic.name: Pisoplinthic
Pisoplinthic.description: (from Latin pisum, pea, and Greek plinthos, brick): having a pisoplinthic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Placic.name: Placic
Placic.description: (from Greek plax, flat stone): having a layer, between ? 0.1 and < 2.5 cm thick, within ? 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, that is cemented or indurated by a combination of organic matter, Fe, Mn and/or Al and is continuous to the extent that vertical fractures, if present, have an average horizontal spacing of ? 10 cm and occupy < 20% (by volume) (2: Epi-, Endo- and Amphi- only).

Xanthic.name: Xanthic
Xanthic.description: (from Greek xanthos, yellow): having a ferralic horizon that has in a subhorizon ? 30 cm thick, and starting ? 75 cm of the upper limit of the ferralic horizon, in ? 90% of its exposed area, a Munsell colour hue of 7.5YR or yellower, a value of ? 4 and a chroma of ? 5, all moist.

Silandic.name: Silandic
Silandic.description: (from Latin silicia, silicon-containing material, and Japanese an, dark, and do, soil): having within ? 100 cm of the soil surface one or more layers with a combined thickness of ? 15 cm with andic properties and a Siox content of ? 0.6% or an Alpy/Alox of < 0.5 (in Andosols only) (2).

Gelistagnic.name: Gelistagnic
Gelistagnic.description: (from Latin gelare, to freeze, and stagnare, to stagnate): having temporary water saturation caused by a frozen layer.

Rustic.name: Rustic
Rustic.description: (from English rust): having a spodic horizon in which the ratio of the percentage of Feox to the percentage of soil organic carbon is ? 6 throughout (in Podzols only).

Mazic.name: Mazic
Mazic.description: (from Spanish maza, cudgel): massive and hard to very hard in the upper 20 cm of the soil (in Vertisols only).

Eutric.name: Eutric
Eutric.description: (from Greek eu, good, and trophae, food): having: � in Histosols, a pHwater ? 5.5 in the major part with organic material, within 100 cm of the soil surface, � in other soils, an effective base saturation [exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na) / exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na + Al); exchangeable bases by 1 M NH4OAc (pH 7), exchangeable Al by 1 M KCl (unbuffered)] of ? 50%: * in the major part between 20 and 100 cm from the mineral soil surface, or * in the major part between 20 cm from the mineral soil surface and continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting > 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, or * in a layer ? 5 cm thick, directly above continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting ? 25 cm from the mineral soil surface (3).

Gypsifractic.name: Gypsifractic
Gypsifractic.description: (from Greek gypsos, gypsum): having a layer ? 10 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, consisting of a broken petrogypsic horizon, the remnants of which: � occupy a volume of ? 40%, and � have an average horizontal length of < 10 cm and/or occupy a volume of < 80% (2).

Ombric.name: Ombric
Ombric.description: (from Greek ombros, rain): having a histic horizon saturated predominantly with rainwater (in Histosols only).

Hyperduric.name: Hyperduric
Hyperduric.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having a duric horizon with ? 50% (by volume) durinodes or fragments of a broken-up petroduric horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Turbic.name: Turbic
Turbic.description: (from Latin turbare, to disturb): having cryoturbation features (mixed material, disrupted soil horizons, involutions, organic intrusions, frost heave, separation of coarse from fine materials, cracks or patterned ground) within 100 cm of the soil surface, above a cryic horizon or above a seasonally frozen layer (2: only if clearly recognizable as layer).

Hyposulfidic.name: Hyposulfidic
Hyposulfidic.description: (from Greek hypo, under): having hyposulfidic material ? 15 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Grumic.name: Grumic
Grumic.description: (from Latin grumus, soil heap): having a soil surface layer ? 1 cm thick, with a strong granular structure, coarse (10 mm) or finer, i.e. �self-mulching� (in Vertisols only).

Rheic.name: Rheic
Rheic.description: (from Greek rhen, to flow): having a histic horizon saturated predominantly with groundwater or flowing water (in Histosols only).

Someriumbric.name: Someriumbric
Someriumbric.description: (from Spanish somero, superficial): having an umbric horizon, < 20 cm thick.

Prototephric.name: Prototephric
Prototephric.description: (from Greek protou, before): having a layer with tephric material ? 10 and < 30 cm thick, and starting ? 50 cm from the soil surface and not reaching continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer.

Sideralic.name: Sideralic
Sideralic.description: (from Greek sideros, iron, and Latin alumen, alum): having within ? 100 cm of the soil surface a layer that has sideralic properties (2).

Transportic.name: Transportic
Transportic.description: (from Latin transportare, to transport): having at the soil surface a layer ? 20 cm thick, or with a thickness of ? 50% of the entire soil if continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer is starting ? 40 cm from the soil surface, with soil material that does not meet the criteria of artefacts; and that has been moved from a source area outside the immediate vicinity of the soil by intentional human activity, usually with the aid of machinery, and without substantial reworking or displacement by natural forces (2: Ano- and Panto- only; no subqualifier if continuous rock or technic hard material starts ? 40 cm from the mineral soil surface).

Orthoskeletic.name: Orthoskeletic
Orthoskeletic.description: (from Greek orthos, right): having: � ? 40% of the soil surface covered by fragments that have a greatest dimension ? 6 cm (stones, boulders or large boulders), and � ? 40% (by volume) coarse fragments averaged over a depth of 100 cm from the soil surface or to continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer, whichever is shallower (5).

Petrocalcic.name: Petrocalcic
Petrocalcic.description: (from Greek petros, rock, and Latin calx, lime): having a petrocalcic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Vertic.name: Vertic
Vertic.description: (from Latin vertere, to turn): having a vertic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Carbonatic.name: Carbonatic
Carbonatic.description: (from Latin carbo, coal): having a salic horizon with a soil solution (1:1 in water) with a pH of ? 8.5 and [HCO3 - ] > [SO4 2-] > 2*[Cl- ] (in Solonchaks only).

Nitic.name: Nitic
Nitic.description: (from Latin nitidus, shiny): having a nitic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface. (2)

Colluvic.name: Colluvic
Colluvic.description: (from Latin colluvio, mixture): having colluvic material ? 20 cm thick, and starting at the mineral soil surface (2: Ano- and Panto- only).

Hypercalcic.name: Hypercalcic
Hypercalcic.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having a calcic horizon with a calcium carbonate equivalent in the fine earth fraction of ? 50% (by mass) and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Hyperorganic.name: Hyperorganic
Hyperorganic.description: (from Greek hyper, over, and organon, tool): having organic material ? 200 cm thick (in Histosols only).

Petroplinthic.name: Petroplinthic
Petroplinthic.description: (from Greek petros, rock, and plinthos, brick): having a petroplinthic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Lixic.name: Lixic
Lixic.description: (from Latin lixivia, washed-out substances): having an argic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface and having a CEC (by 1 M NH4OAc, pH 7) of < 24 cmolc kg-1 clay in some part ? 50 cm below its upper limit; and having an effective base saturation [exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na) / exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na + Al); exchangeable bases by 1 M NH4OAc (pH 7), exchangeable Al by 1 M KCl (unbuffered)] of ? 50% in the major part between 50 and 100 cm from the mineral soil surface or in the lower half of the mineral soil above continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting ? 100 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is shallower (2).

Escalic.name: Escalic
Escalic.description: (from Spanish escala, terrace): occurring in human-made terraces.

Neocambic.name: Neocambic
Neocambic.description: (from Greek neos, new): having a cambic horizon, not consisting of albic material, starting ? 50 cm from the soil surface and overlying: � albic material that overlies an argic, a natric or a spodic horizon, or � a layer with retic properties.

Alic.name: Alic
Alic.description: (from Latin alumen, alum): having an argic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface and having a CEC (by 1 M NH4OAc, pH 7) of ? 24 cmolc kg-1 clay throughout or to a depth of 50 cm of its upper limit, whichever is thinner; and having an effective base saturation [exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na) / exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na + Al); exchangeable bases by 1 M NH4OAc (pH 7), exchangeable Al by 1 M KCl (unbuffered)] of < 50% in half or more of the part between 50 and 100 cm from the mineral soil surface or in the lower half of the mineral soil above continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting ? 100 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is shallower (2).

Nudinatric.name: Nudinatric
Nudinatric.description: (from Latin nudus, naked): having a natric horizon starting at the mineral soil surface.

Plinthic.name: Plinthic
Plinthic.description: (from Greek plinthos, brick): having a plinthic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Capillaric.name: Capillaric
Capillaric.description: (from Latin capillus, hair): having a layer ? 25 cm thick that has so few macropores that water saturation of capillary pores causes reducing conditions (2).

Fractic.name: Fractic
Fractic.description: (from Latin fractus, broken): having a layer ? 10 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, consisting of a broken cemented or indurated horizon, the remnants of which: � occupy a volume of ? 40%, and � have an average horizontal length of < 10 cm and/or occupy a volume of < 80% (2).

Hypogypsic.name: Hypogypsic
Hypogypsic.description: (from Greek hypo, under): having a gypsic horizon with a gypsum content in the fine earth fraction of < 25% (by mass) and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Haplic.name: Haplic
Haplic.description: (from Greek haplous, simple): having a typical expression of certain features (typical in the sense that there is no further or meaningful characterization) and only used if none of the preceding qualifiers applies.

Orthidystric.name: Orthidystric
Orthidystric.description:
(from Greek orthos, right): having: � in Histosols, a pHwater < 5.5 throughout in the organic material within 100 cm of the soil surface, � in other soils, an effective base saturation [exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na) / exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na + Al); exchangeable bases by 1 M NH4OAc (pH 7), exchangeable Al by 1 M KCl (unbuffered)] of < 50% throughout
between 20 and 100 cm from the mineral soil surface.

Natric.name: Natric
Natric.description: (from Arabic natroon, salt): having a natric horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Reductaquic.name: Reductaquic
Reductaquic.description: (from Latin reductus, drawn back, and aqua, water): having a layer ? 25 cm thick, and starting ? 75 cm from the mineral soil surface, that is saturated with water during the thawing period and that has at some time of the year reducing conditions above a cryic horizon and within ? 100 cm of the mineral soil surface (in Cryosols only) (2).

Hypocalcic.name: Hypocalcic
Hypocalcic.description: (from Greek hypo, under): having a calcic horizon with a calcium carbonate equivalent in the fine earth fraction of < 25% (by mass) and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Mineralic.name: Mineralic
Mineralic.description: (from Celtic mine, mineral): having, within ? 100 cm of the soil surface, one or more layers of mineral material with a combined thickness of ? 20 cm, in between layers of organic material (in Histosols only) (2: Epi-, Endo-, Amphi- and Kato- only).

Gelic.name: Gelic
Gelic.description: (from Latin gelare, to freeze): � having a layer with a soil temperature of ? 0 �C for ? 2 consecutive years, starting ? 200 cm from the soil surface, and � not having a cryic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, and � not having a cryic horizon starting ? 200 cm from the soil surface with evidence of cryoturbation in some layer within ? 100 cm of the soil surface (1; Epi- and Endo- only).

Technolithic.name: Technolithic
Technolithic.description: (from Greek technae, art): having technic hard material starting ? 10 cm from the soil surface (in Leptosols only).

Posic.name: Posic
Posic.description: (from Latin positivus, given): having layer ? 30 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, that has a zero or positive charge (pHKCl - pHwater ? 0, both in 1:1 solution) (2).

Andic.name: Andic
Andic.description: (from Japanese an, dark, and do, soil): having within ? 100 cm of the soil surface one or more layers with andic or vitric properties with a combined thickness of ? 30 cm (in Cambisols ? 15 cm), of which ? 15 cm (in Cambisols ? 7.5 cm) have andic properties (2).

Anthrotoxic.name: Anthrotoxic
Anthrotoxic.description: (from Greek anthropos, human being): having in some layer within ? 50 cm of the soil surface, sufficiently high and persistent concentrations of organic or inorganic substances to markedly affect the health of humans who come in regular contact with the soil.

Petrogleyic.name: Petrogleyic
Petrogleyic.description: (from Greek petros, rock, and Russian gley, mucky soil mass): having a layer ? 10 cm thick, within ? 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, that meets diagnostic criterion 2 of the gleyic properties and of which ? 15% (by volume) is cemented (bog iron) (2).

Rhodic.name: Rhodic
Rhodic.description: (from Greek rhodon, rose): having between 25 and 150 cm of the soil surface, a layer ? 30 cm thick, that has, in ? 90% of its exposed area, a Munsell colour hue redder than 5YR moist, a value of < 4 moist, and a value dry, no more than one unit higher than the moist value (2: except Epi-).

Oxyaquic.name: Oxyaquic
Oxyaquic.description: (from Greek oxys, sour, and Latin aqua, water): having a layer ? 25 cm thick, and starting ? 75 cm from the mineral soil surface, that is saturated with oxygen-rich water during a period of ? 20 consecutive days; and not having gleyic or stagnic properties in any layer within ? 100 cm of the mineral soil surface (2).

Lapiadic.name: Lapiadic
Lapiadic.description: (from Latin lapis, stone): having at the soil surface continuous rock that has dissolution features (rills, grooves), ? 20 cm deep and covering ? 10 and < 50% of the surface of the continuous rock (in Leptosols only).

Hyperalic.name: Hyperalic
Hyperalic.description: (from Greek hyper, over, and Latin alumen, alum): having an argic horizon, starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, that has a silt to clay ratio of < 0.6 and an Al saturation (effective) of ? 50%, throughout or to a depth of 50 cm below its upper limit, whichever is thinner (in Alisols only).

Petrogypsic.name: Petrogypsic
Petrogypsic.description: (from Greek petros, rock, and gypsos, gypsum): having a petrogypsic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Mollic.name: Mollic
Mollic.description: (from Latin mollis, soft): having a mollic horizon (2: Ano- and Pantoonly).

Arzic.name: Arzic
Arzic.description: (from Turkish arz, land or earth�s crust): having sulfate-rich groundwater in some layer within ? 50 cm of the soil surface during some time in most years and containing ? 15% (by volume) gypsum averaged over a depth of 100 cm from the soil surface or to continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer, whichever is shallower (in Gypsisols only).

Greyzemic.name: Greyzemic
Greyzemic.description: (from English grey, and Russian zemlya, earth): having uncoated silt and sand grains on structural faces in the lower half of a mollic horizon.

Acroxic.name: Acroxic
Acroxic.description: (from Latin acer, sharp, and Greek oxys, sour): having within ? 100 cm of the soil surface one or more layers with a combined thickness of ? 30 cm, and with < 2 cmolc kg-1 fine earth exchangeable bases (by 1 M NH4OAc, pH 7) plus exchangeable Al (by 1 M KCl, unbuffered) (in Andosols only) (2).

Folic.name: Folic
Folic.description: having a folic horizon starting at the soil surface.

Lignic.name: Lignic
Lignic.description: (from Latin lignum, wood): having inclusions of intact wood fragments that make up ? 25% of the soil volume, within 50 cm from the soil surface.

Loaminovic.name: Loaminovic
Loaminovic.description: (from English loam): having a layer, ? 5 cm and < 50 cm thick, with a texture class of loam, sandy loam, sandy clay loam, clay loam or silty clay loam in its major part, overlying a buried soil that is classified with preference according to the �Rules for classifying soils� (Chapter 2.5).

Plaggic.name: Plaggic
Plaggic.description: (from Low German plaggen, sod): having a plaggic horizon (2: Pantoonly).

Glossic.name: Glossic
Glossic.description: (from Greek glossa, tongue): having albeluvic glossae starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface.

Fluvic.name: Fluvic
Fluvic.description: (from Latin fluvius, river): having fluvic material ? 25 cm thick, and starting ? 75 cm from the mineral soil surface (2).

Totilamellic.name: Totilamellic
Totilamellic.description: (from Latin totus, complete): having an argic horizon that consists entirely of lamellae starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface.

Brunic.name: Brunic
Brunic.description: (from Low German brun, brown): having a layer ? 15 cm thick, and starting ? 50 cm from the soil surface, that meets diagnostic criteria 2�4 of the cambic horizon but fails diagnostic criterion 1, and does not consist of albic material.

Protosalic.name: Protosalic
Protosalic.description: (from Greek protou, before): having within ? 100 cm of the soil surface a layer that has an ECe of ? 4 dS m-1 at 25 �C; and not having a salic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Ferralic.name: Ferralic
Ferralic.description: (from Latin ferrum, iron, and alumen, alum): having a ferralic horizon starting ? 150 cm of the soil surface (2).

Uterquic.name: Uterquic
Uterquic.description: (from Latin uterque, both): having a layer with dominant gleyic properties and some parts with stagnic properties.

Rubic.name: Rubic
Rubic.description: (from Latin ruber, red): having between 25 and 100 cm of the soil surface, a layer ? 30 cm thick, that does not consist of albic material and that has, in ? 90% of its exposed area, a Munsell colour hue redder than 10YR and/or a chroma of ? 5, both moist (in Arenosols only) (2: except Epi-).

Histic.name: Histic
Histic.description: (from Greek histos, tissue): having a histic horizon starting at the soil surface.

Protovertic.name: Protovertic
Protovertic.description: (from Greek protou, before): having a protovertic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surfaced; and not having a vertic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Nudiyermic.name: Nudiyermic
Nudiyermic.description: (from Latin nudus, naked): having yermic properties without a desert pavement.

Clayinovic.name: Clayinovic
Clayinovic.description: (from English clay): having a layer, ? 5 cm and < 50 cm thick, with a texture class of clay, sandy clay or silty clay in its major part, overlying a buried soil that is classified with preference according to the �Rules for classifying soils� (Chapter 2.5).

Hypernatric.name: Hypernatric
Hypernatric.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having a natric horizon with an exchangeable Na percentage (ESP) of ? 15 throughout the entire natric horizon or within its upper 40 cm, whichever is thinner.

Tonguic.name: Tonguic
Tonguic.description: (from English tongue): showing tonguing of a chernic, mollic or umbric horizon into an underlying layer.

Petrosalic.name: Petrosalic
Petrosalic.description: (from Greek petros, rock, and Latin sal, salt): having a layer ? 10 cm thick, within ? 100 cm of the soil surface, which is cemented by salts more soluble than gypsum (2).

Tidalic.name: Tidalic
Tidalic.description: (from English tide): affected by tidal water, i.e. located between the line of mean high water springs and the line of mean low water springs.

Albic.name: Albic
Albic.description: (from Latin albus, white): having a layer of albic material ? 1 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the mineral soil surface, that does not consist of tephric material, does not contain carbonates, and does not contain gypsum; and that overlies a diagnostic horizon or forms part of a layer with stagnic properties (2).

Orthofluvic.name: Orthofluvic
Orthofluvic.description: (from Greek orthos, right): having fluvic material: � from the mineral soil surface to a depth of ? 5 cm, and * ? 25 cm thick, and starting ? 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, or * from the lower limit of a plough layer that is ? 40 cm thick, to a depth of ? 50 cm from the mineral soil surface.

Umbric.name: Umbric
Umbric.description: (from Latin umbra, shade): having an umbric horizon (2: Ano- and Panto- only).

Infraspodic.name: Infraspodic
Infraspodic.description: (from Latin infra, below, and Greek spodos, wood ash): having a layer that underlies a soil classified with preference according to the �Rules for classifying soils� (Chapter 2.5) and that meets diagnostic criteria 3 to 6 of the spodic horizon and fails diagnostic criterion 1 or 2 or both.

Protospodic.name: Protospodic
Protospodic.description: (from Greek protou, before): having a layer ? 2.5 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the mineral soil surface, that has: � ? 0.5% soil organic carbon in its uppermost 1 cm, and � a sublayer with an Alox + �Feox value of ? 0.5% that is ? 2 times higher than the lowest Alox + �Feox value of all overlying mineral layers; and not having a spodic horizon starting ? 200 cm from the mineral soil surface (2).

Abruptic.name: Abruptic
Abruptic.description: (from Latin abruptus, broken away): having an abrupt textural difference within ? 100 cm of the mineral soil surface (1).

Skeletic.name: Skeletic
Skeletic.description: (from Greek skeletos, dried out): having ? 40% (by volume) coarse fragments averaged over a depth of 100 cm from the soil surface or to continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer, whichever is shallower (5).

Entic.name: Entic
Entic.description: (from Latin recens, young): having a loose spodic horizon and not having a layer with albic material (in Podzols only).

Eutrisilic.name: Eutrisilic
Eutrisilic.description: (from Greek eu, good, and trophae, food, and Latin silicia, siliconcontaining material): having within ? 100 cm of the soil surface one or more layers with a combined thickness of ? 30 cm, with andic properties and a sum of exchangeable bases (by 1 M NH4OAc, pH 7) of ? 15 cmolc kg-1 fine earth (in Andosols only) (2).

Sapric.name: Sapric
Sapric.description: (from Greek sapros, rotted): having, after rubbing, less than one-sixth (by volume) of the organic material consisting of recognizable plant tissue within 100 cm of the soil surface (in Histosols only).

Carbic.name: Carbic
Carbic.description: (from Latin carbo, coal): having a spodic horizon that does not turn redder on ignition throughout (in Podzols only).

Hyperspodic.name: Hyperspodic
Hyperspodic.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having a spodic horizon ? 100 cm thick.

Linic.name: Linic
Linic.description: (from Latin linea, line): having a continuous, very slowly permeable to impermeable constructed geomembrane of any thickness starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (1).

Profundihumic.name: Profundihumic
Profundihumic.description: (from Latin profundus, deep): having ? 1.4% soil organic carbon in the fine earth fraction as a weighted average to a depth of 100 cm from the mineral soil surface.

Clayic.name: Clayic
Clayic.description: (from English clay): having a texture class of clay, sandy clay or silty clay, in a layer ? 30 cm thick, within ? 100 cm of the mineral soil surface or in the major part between the mineral soil surface and continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting < 60 cm from the mineral soil surface (2; no subqualifier if continuous rock or technic hard material starts < 60 cm from the mineral soil surface).

Cambic.name: Cambic
Cambic.description: (from Late Latin cambiare, to change): having a cambic horizon not consisting of albic material and starting ? 50 cm from the soil surface.

Akromineralic.name: Akromineralic
Akromineralic.description: (from Greek akra, top): having mineral material, ? 5 cm thick, starting at the soil surface, but the layers of mineral material above or in between layers of organic material have a combined thickness of < 20 cm (in Histosols only).

Aric.name: Aric
Aric.description: (from Latin arare, to plough): being ploughed to a depth of ? 20 cm from the soil surface (2: Ano- and Panto- only).

Gilgaic.name: Gilgaic
Gilgaic.description: (from Aboriginal Australian gilgai, water hole): having at the soil surface, microhighs and microlows with a difference in level of ? 10 cm, i.e. gilgai microrelief (in Vertisols only).

Protoandic.name: Protoandic
Protoandic.description: (from Greek protou, before): having within ? 100 cm of the soil surface one or more layers with a combined thickness of ? 15 cm, and with an Alox + �Feox value of ? 1.2%, a bulk density23 of ? 1 kg dm-3 and a phosphate retention of ? 55%; and not fulfilling the set of criteria of the Andic qualifier (2).

Zootoxic.name: Zootoxic
Zootoxic.description: (from Greek zoae, life): having in some layer within ? 50 cm of the soil surface, sufficiently high and persistent concentrations of organic or inorganic substances to markedly affect the health of animals, including humans, that ingest plants grown on these soils.

Organotransportic.name: Organotransportic
Organotransportic.description: (from Greek organon, tool): having at the soil surface a layer ? 20 cm thick, or with a thickness of ? 50% of the entire soil if continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer is starting ? 40 cm from the soil surface, with organic material that does not meet the criteria of artefacts; and that has been moved from a source area outside the immediate vicinity of the soil by intentional human activity, usually with the aid of machinery, and without substantial reworking or displacement by natural forces (2: Ano- and Panto- only; no subqualifier if continuous rock or technic hard material starts ? 40 cm from the mineral soil surface).

Aceric.name: Aceric
Aceric.description: (from Latin acer, sharp): having within ? 100 cm of the soil surface a layer with a pH (1:1 in water) between ? 3.5 and < 5 and jarosite mottles (in Solonchaks only) (2).

Siltinovic.name: Siltinovic
Siltinovic.description: (from English silt): having a layer, ? 5 cm and < 50 cm thick, with a texture class of silt or silt loam in its major part, overlying a buried soil that is classified with preference according to the �Rules for classifying soils� (Chapter 2.5).

Someric.name: Someric
Someric.description: (from Spanish somero, superficial): having a mollic or umbric horizon, < 20 cm thick.

Dolomitic.name: Dolomitic
Dolomitic.description: (from the mineral dolomite, named after the French geoscientist D�odat de Dolomieu): having dolomitic material throughout between 20 and 100 cm from the soil surface or between 20 cm and continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer, whichever is shallower (4).

Fragic.name: Fragic
Fragic.description: (from Latin fragilis, fragile): having a fragic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Duric.name: Duric
Duric.description: (from Latin durus, hard): having a duric horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Hyperferritic.name: Hyperferritic
Hyperferritic.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having a layer ? 30 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, with Fedith in the fine earth fraction of ? 30% and not forming part of a petroplinthic, pisoplinthic or plinthic horizon (2).

Cutanic.name: Cutanic
Cutanic.description: (from Latin cutis, skin): having an argic or natric horizon that meets diagnostic criterion 2b for the respective horizon.

Aeolic.name: Aeolic
Aeolic.description: (from Greek aiolos, wind): having at the soil surface a layer, ? 10 cm thick, the material of which is deposited by wind and has < 0.6% soil organic carbon (2: Ano- and Panto- only).

Anthric.name: Anthric
Anthric.description: (from Greek anthropos, human being): having anthric properties.

Geric.name: Geric
Geric.description: (from Greek geraios, old): having within ? 100 cm of the soil surface a layer with geric properties (2).

Tonguimollic.name: Tonguimollic
Tonguimollic.description: (from English tongue): having a mollic horizon that tongues into an underlying layer (2: Ano- and Panto- only; referring to the mollic horizon, not to the tongues).

Reductic.name: Reductic
Reductic.description: (from Latin reductus, drawn back): having reducing conditions in ? 25% of the volume of the fine earth within 100 cm of the soil surface, caused by gaseous emissions, e.g. methane or carbon dioxide, or caused by liquid intrusions other than water, e.g. gasoline (5).

Sulfatic.name: Sulfatic
Sulfatic.description: (from Latin sulpur, sulfur): having a salic horizon with a soil solution (1:1 in water) with [SO4 2-] > 2*[HCO3 - ] > 2*[Cl- ] (in Solonchaks only).

Dystric.name: Dystric
Dystric.description: (from Greek dys, bad, and trophae, food): having: � in Histosols, a pHwater < 5.5 in half or more of the part with organic material, within 100 cm of the soil surface, � in other soils, an effective base saturation [exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na) / exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na + Al); exchangeable bases by 1 M NH4OAc (pH 7), exchangeable Al by 1 M KCl (unbuffered)] of < 50%: * in half or more of the part between 20 and 100 cm from the mineral soil surface, or * in half or more of the part between 20 cm from the mineral soil surface and continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting > 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, or * in a layer ? 5 cm thick, directly above continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting ? 25 cm from the mineral soil surface (3).

Inclinic.name: Inclinic
Inclinic.description: (from Latin inclinare, to bow): having � a slope inclination of ? 5%, and � a layer ? 25 cm thick, and starting ? 75 cm from the mineral soil surface, with gleyic or stagnic properties and a subsurface water flow for some time during the year.

Protoaridic.name: Protoaridic
Protoaridic.description: (from Greek protou, before): having a mineral topsoil layer ? 5 cm thick, with a Munsell colour value, dry, of ? 5 that turns darker on moistening; < 0.4% soil organic carbon, a platy structure in ? 50% of the volume, a surface crust; and not having aridic properties.

Hypothionic.name: Hypothionic
Hypothionic.description: (from Greek hypo, under): having a thionic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface and having a pH (1:1 in water) between ? 3.5 and < 4 (2).

Takyric.name: Takyric
Takyric.description: (from Turkic languages takyr, barren land): having takyric properties

Reductigleyic.name: Reductigleyic
Reductigleyic.description: (Latin reductus, drawn back, and Russian gley, mucky soil mass): not having, ? 40 cm from the mineral soil surface, a layer that meets diagnostic criterion 2 of the gleyic properties (in Gleysols only).

Vermic.name: Vermic
Vermic.description: (from Latin vermis, worm): having ? 50% (by volume, weighted average) of worm holes, casts, or filled animal burrows in the upper 100 cm of the soil or to continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer, whichever is shallower.

Nudilithic.name: Nudilithic
Nudilithic.description: (from Latin nudus, naked): having continuous rock at the surface (in Leptosols only).

Rockic.name: Rockic
Rockic.description: (from English rock): having continuous rock or technic hard material that is directly overlain by organic material (in Histosols only) (1: Epi- and Endoonly).

Ekranic.name: Ekranic
Ekranic.description: (from French �cran, shield): having technic hard material starting ? 5 cm from the soil surface (in Technosols only).

Hydric.name: Hydric
Hydric.description: (from Greek hydor, water): having within ? 100 cm of the soil surface one or more layers with a combined thickness of ? 35 cm that have a water content ? 100% at 1500 kPa tension, measured without previous drying of the sample (in Andosols only) (2).

Somerirendzic.name: Somerirendzic
Somerirendzic.description: (from Spanish somero, superficial): having a mollic horizon, < 20 cm thick, that directly overlies calcareous rock containing ? 40% calcium carbonate equivalent.

Tonguichernic.name: Tonguichernic
Tonguichernic.description: (from English tongue): having a chernic horizon that tongues into an underlying layer (2: Ano- and Panto- only).

Evapocrustic.name: Evapocrustic
Evapocrustic.description: (from Latin e, out, and vapor, steam, and crusta, crust): having a saline crust ? 2 cm thick, on the soil surface (in Solonchaks only).

Ortsteinic.name: Ortsteinic
Ortsteinic.description: (from German Ortstein, locally occurring stone): having a spodic horizon that has a subhorizon, ? 2.5 cm thick, that is cemented ('ortstein') in ? 50% of its horizontal extension (in Podzols only).

Chloridic.name: Chloridic
Chloridic.description: (from Greek chloros, yellow-green): having a salic horizon with a soil solution (1:1 in water) with [Cl- ] > 2*[SO4 2-] > 2*[HCO3 - ] (in Solonchaks only).

Petroduric.name: Petroduric
Petroduric.description: (from Greek petros, rock, and Latin durus, hard): having a petroduric horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Relictistagnic.name: Relictistagnic
Relictistagnic.description: (from Latin relictus, left back): having a layer ? 25 cm thick, and starting ? 75 cm from the mineral soil surface, that has: � stagnic properties in which the area of reductimorphic colours plus the area of oximorphic colours is ? 25% of the layer's total area, and � no reducing conditions (2).

Relictiturbic.name: Relictiturbic
Relictiturbic.description: (from Latin relictus, left back): having cryoturbation features within 100 cm of the soil surface, caused by frost action in the past (2: only if clearly recognizable as layer).

Rendzic.name: Rendzic
Rendzic.description: (from Polish rzendzic, to grate in contact with a plough blade): having a mollic horizon that contains or directly overlies calcaric material containing ? 40% calcium carbonate equivalent or that directly overlies calcareous rock containing ? 40% calcium carbonate equivalent (2: Ano- and Panto- only).

Cryic.name: Cryic
Cryic.description: (from Greek kryos, cold, ice): having a cryic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, or having a cryic horizon starting ? 200 cm from the soil surface with evidence of cryoturbation in some layer ? 100 cm from the soil surface (1; Epi- and Endo- only; referring to the upper limit of the cryic horizon).

Ferric.name: Ferric
Ferric.description: (from Latin ferrum, iron): having a ferric horizon starting ? 100 cm of the soil surface (2).

Laxic.name: Laxic
Laxic.description: (from Latin laxus, slack): having between 25 and 75 cm from the mineral soil surface a mineral soil layer ? 20 cm thick, that has a bulk density24 of ? 0.9 kg dm-3.

Siltic.name: Siltic
Siltic.description: (from English silt): having a texture class of silt or silt loam in a layer ? 30 cm thick, within ? 100 cm of the mineral soil surface or in the major part between the mineral soil surface and continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting < 60 cm from the mineral soil surface (2; no subqualifier if continuous rock or technic hard material starts < 60 cm from the mineral soil surface).

Fulvic.name: Fulvic
Fulvic.description: (from Latin fulvus, dark yellow): having a fulvic horizon starting ? 30 cm from the soil surface (2: except Endo-).

Protosodic.name: Protosodic
Protosodic.description: (from Greek protou, before): having a layer ? 20 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, that has ? 6% Na on the exchange complex; and not having a natric horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Calcic.name: Calcic
Calcic.description: (from Latin calx, lime): having a calcic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Technoleptic.name: Technoleptic
Technoleptic.description: (from Greek technae, art): having technic hard material starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (1: Epi- and Endo- only).

Tonguiumbric.name: Tonguiumbric
Tonguiumbric.description: (from English tongue): having an umbric horizon that tongues into an underlying layer (2: Ano- and Panto- only; referring to the umbric horizon, not to the tongues).

Loamic.name: Loamic
Loamic.description: (from English loam): having a texture class of loam, sandy loam, sandy clay loam, clay loam or silty clay loam in a layer ? 30 cm thick, within ? 100 cm of the mineral soil surface or in the major part between the mineral soil surface and continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting < 60 cm from the mineral soil surface (2; no subqualifier if continuous rock or technic hard material starts < 60 cm from the mineral soil surface).

Magnesic.name: Magnesic
Magnesic.description: (from the chemical element magnesium - no agreed etymology): having an exchangeable Ca to Mg ratio of < 1 in the major part within 100 cm of the soil surface or to continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer, whichever is shallower (3).

Raptic.name: Raptic
Raptic.description: (from Latin raptus, broken): having a lithic discontinuity at some depth ? 100 cm from the mineral soil surface (1).

Akrofluvic.name: Akrofluvic
Akrofluvic.description: (from Greek akra, top): having fluvic material from the mineral soil surface to a depth of ? 5 cm, but < 25 cm thick (note: in addition to the Akrofluvic subqualifier, a soil may also have the Amphifluvic, the Katofluvic or the Endofluvic subqualifier).

Isolatic.name: Isolatic
Isolatic.description: (from Italian isola, island): having, above technic hard material, above a geomembrane or above a continuous layer of artefacts starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, soil material containing fine earth without any contact to other soil material containing fine earth (e.g. soils on roofs or in pots).

Aluandic.name: Aluandic
Aluandic.description: (from Latin alumen, alum, and Japanese an, dark, and do, soil): having within ? 100 cm of the soil surface one or more layers with a combined thickness of ? 15 cm with andic properties and a Siox content of < 0.6% and an Alpy/Alox of ? 0.5 (in Andosols only) (2).

Phytotoxic.name: Phytotoxic
Phytotoxic.description: (from Greek phyton, plant): having in some layer within ? 50 cm of the soil surface, sufficiently high concentrations of ions other than Al, Fe, Na, Ca and Mg, to markedly affect plant growth.

Alcalic.name: Alcalic
Alcalic.description: (from Arabic al-qali, salt-containing ash): having: � a pH (1:1 in water) of ? 8.5 throughout within ? 50 cm of the mineral soil surface, or to continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer, whichever is shallower, and � an effective base saturation [exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na) / exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na + Al); exchangeable bases by 1 M NH4OAc (pH 7), exchangeable Al by 1 M KCl (unbuffered)] of ? 50%: * in the major part between 20 and 100 cm from the mineral soil surface or * in the major part between 20 cm and continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting > 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, or * in a layer ? 5 cm thick, directly above continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting ? 25 cm from the mineral soil surface.

Hyperhumic.name: Hyperhumic
Hyperhumic.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having ? 5% soil organic carbon in the fine earth fraction as a weighted average to a depth of 50 cm from the mineral soil surface.

Hyperdystric.name: Hyperdystric
Hyperdystric.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having: � in Histosols, a pHwater < 5.5 throughout in the organic material within 100 cm of the soil surface and < 50% throughout between 20 and 100 cm from the mineral soil surface, and < 20% in some layer between 20 and 100 cm from the mineral soil surface.

Columnic.name: Columnic
Columnic.description: (from Latin columna, column): having a layer ? 15 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, that has a columnar structure (2).

Oxygleyic.name: Oxygleyic
Oxygleyic.description: (from Greek oxys, sour, and Russian gley, mucky soil mass): not having, within ? 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, a layer that meets diagnostic criterion 1 of the gleyic properties (in Gleysols only).

Luvic.name: Luvic
Luvic.description:
(from Latin eluere, to wash): having an argic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface and having a CEC (by 1 M NH4OAc, pH 7) of ? 24 cmolc kg-1 clay throughout or to a depth of 50 cm of its upper limit, whichever is thinner; and having an effective base saturation [exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na) / exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na + Al); exchangeable bases by 1 M NH4OAc (pH 7), exchangeable Al by 1 M KCl (unbuffered)] of ? 50% in the
major part between 50 and 100 cm from the mineral soil surface or in the lower
half of the mineral soil above continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented
or indurated layer starting ? 100 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is
shallower (2).

Archaic.name: Archaic
Archaic.description: (from Greek archae, beginning): having a layer ? 20 cm thick, within ? 100 cm of the soil surface, with ? 20% (by volume, weighted average) artefacts containing ? 50% (by volume) artefacts produced by pre-industrial processes, e.g. ceramics, showing traces of production by hand, ceramics that can easily be broken or ceramics containing sand (in Technosols only) (2).

Fibric.name: Fibric
Fibric.description: (from Latin fibra, fiber): having, after rubbing, two-thirds or more (by volume) of the organic material consisting of recognizable plant tissue within 100 cm of the soil surface (in Histosols only).

Sulfidic.name: Sulfidic
Sulfidic.description: (from Latin sulpur, sulfur): having sulfidic material ? 15 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Chernic.name: Chernic
Chernic.description: (from Russian chorniy, black): having a chernic horizon (2: Ano- and Panto- only).

Hydragric.name: Hydragric
Hydragric.description: (from Greek hydor, water, and Latin ager, field): having an anthraquic horizon and a directly underlying hydragric horizon, the latter starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface.

Spodic.name: Spodic
Spodic.description: (from Greek spodos, wood ash): having a spodic horizon starting ? 200 cm from the mineral soil surface (2).

Hortic.name: Hortic
Hortic.description: (from Latin hortus, garden): having a hortic horizon (2: Panto- only).

Orthomineralic.name: Orthomineralic
Orthomineralic.description: (from Greek orthos, right): having: � mineral material, ? 5 cm thick, starting at the soil surface, and � within ? 100 cm of the soil surface, one or more layers of mineral material with a combined thickness of ? 20 cm, above or in between layers of organic material (in Histosols only).

Nudiargic.name: Nudiargic
Nudiargic.description: (from Latin nudus, naked, and argilla, white clay): having an argic horizon starting at the mineral soil surface.

Chromic.name: Chromic
Chromic.description: (from Greek chroma, colour): having between 25 and 150 cm of the soil surface a layer, ? 30 cm thick, that has, in ? 90% of its exposed area, a Munsell colour hue redder than 7.5YR and a chroma of > 4, both moist (2: except Epi-).

Irragric.name: Irragric
Irragric.description: (from Latin irrigare, to irrigate, and ager, field): having an irragric horizon (2: Panto- only).

Spolic.name: Spolic
Spolic.description:
(from Latin spoliare, to exploit): having a layer ? 20 cm thick, within ? 100 cm of the soil surface, with ? 20% (by volume, weighted average) artefacts containing ? 35% (by volume) industrial waste (mine spoil, dredgings, slag, ash,
rubble, etc.) (in Technosols only) (2).

Vetic.name: Vetic
Vetic.description: (from Latin vetus, old): having between 25 and 100 cm of the soil surface a layer that has a sum of exchangeable bases (by 1 M NH4OAc, pH 7) plus exchangeable Al (by 1 M KCl, unbuffered) of < 6 cmolc kg-1 clay (2).

Murshic.name: Murshic
Murshic.description: (from Polish mursz, decay): having a drained histic horizon ? 20 cm thick, and starting ? 10 cm from the soil surface or below a folic horizon, with a bulk density25 of ? 0.2 kg dm-3 and one or both of the following: � moderate to strong granular or blocky structure, or � cracks (in Histosols only) (2).

Profondic.name: Profondic
Profondic.description: (from French profond, deep): having an argic horizon in which the clay content does not decrease by ? 20% (relative) from its maximum within 150 cm of the soil surface.

Eutrosilic.name: Eutrosilic
Eutrosilic.description: (from Greek eu, good, and trophae, food, and Latin silicia, silicon containing material): having within ≤ 100 cm of the soil surface one or more layers with a combined thickness of ≥ 30 cm, with andic properties and a sum of exchangeable bases (by 1 M NH4OAc, pH 7) of ≥ 15 cmolc kg-1 fine earth (in Andosols only)

Prototechnic.name: Prototechnic
Prototechnic.description: (from Greek protou, before): having ? 5% (by volume, weighted average) artefacts in the upper 100 cm from the soil surface or to continuous rock or a cemented or indurated layer, whichever is shallower; or having a layer ? 10 cm thick, and starting ? 90 cm from the soil surface, with ? 25% (by volume, weighted average) artefacts (5 or 2: Epi- and Endo- only).

Toxic.name: Toxic
Toxic.description: (from Greek toxikon, arrow poison): having in some layer within ? 50 cm of the soil surface, toxic concentrations of organic or inorganic substances other than ions of Al, Fe, Na, Ca and Mg, or having radioactivity dangerous to humans.

Geoabruptic.name: Geoabruptic
Geoabruptic.description: (from Greek gaia, earth): having an abrupt textural difference within ? 100 cm of the mineral soil surface that is not associated with the upper limit of an argic or natric horizon (1).

Hypersalic.name: Hypersalic
Hypersalic.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having within ? 100 cm of the soil surface a layer that has an ECe of ? 30 dS m-1 at 25 �C (2).

Drainic.name: Drainic
Drainic.description: (from French drainer, to drain): having artificial drainage.

Subaquatic.name: Subaquatic
Subaquatic.description: (from Latin sub, under, and aqua, water): being permanently submerged by water not deeper than 200 cm.

Hypersulfidic.name: Hypersulfidic
Hypersulfidic.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having hypersulfidic material ? 15 cm thick, and starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Manganiferric.name: Manganiferric
Manganiferric.description: (from Latin magnesia nigra, black mineral from the city of Magnesia): having a ferric horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface in which ? 50% of the concretions and/or nodules and/or mottles are black (2).

Pretic.name: Pretic
Pretic.description: (from Portuguese preto, black): having a pretic horizon (2: Panto- only).

Vitric.name: Vitric
Vitric.description: (from Latin vitrum, glass): having within ? 100 cm of the soil surface, one or more layers with andic or vitric properties with a combined thickness of ? 30 cm (in Cambisols ? 15 cm), of which ? 15 cm (in Cambisols ? 7.5 cm) have vitric properties (2).

Nudipetric.name: Nudipetric
Nudipetric.description: (from Latin nudus, naked): having a cemented or indurated layer starting at the soil surface (refers to a diagnostic horizon of the respective RSG).

Humic.name: Humic
Humic.description:
(from Latin humus, earth): having ? 1% soil organic carbon in the fine earth fraction as a weighted average to a depth of 50 cm from the mineral soil surface (if continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starts within the specified depth, the depth range below that contributes a 0 to the
calculation).

Pachic.name: Pachic
Pachic.description: (from Greek pachys, thick): having a mollic or umbric horizon ? 50 cm thick.

Protocalcic.name: Protocalcic
Protocalcic.description:
(from Greek protou, before): having a layer with protocalcic
properties starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface and not having a calcic or
petrocalcic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Floatic.name: Floatic
Floatic.description: (from English to float): having organic material floating on water (in Histosols only).

Lamellic.name: Lamellic
Lamellic.description: (from Latin lamella, metal blade): having two or more lamellae (? 0.5 and < 7.5 cm thick) that have higher clay contents than the directly overlying layers as stated in the diagnostic criteria 2.a of the argic horizon, with a combined thickness of ? 5 cm; the uppermost lamella starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Hypermagnesic.name: Hypermagnesic
Hypermagnesic.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having an exchangeable Ca to Mg ratio of < 0.1 in the major part within 100 cm of the soil surface or to continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer, whichever is shallower (3).

Mesotrophic.name: Mesotrophic
Mesotrophic.description: (from Greek mesos, middle, and trophae, food): having an effective base saturation [exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na) / exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na + Al); exchangeable bases by 1 M NH4OAc (pH 7), exchangeable Al by 1 M KCl (unbuffered)] of < 75% at a depth of 20 cm from the soil surface (in Vertisols only).

Petric.name: Petric
Petric.description: (from Greek petros, rock): having a cemented or indurated layer starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (refers to a diagnostic horizon of the respective RSG) (1: Epi- and Endo- only).

Radiotoxic.name: Radiotoxic
Radiotoxic.description: (from Latin radius, ray): having radioactivity, dangerous to humans.

Anthromollic.name: Anthromollic
Anthromollic.description: (from Greek anthropos, human being): having a mollic horizon and anthric properties (2: Ano- and Panto- only).

Salic.name: Salic
Salic.description: (from Latin sal, salt): having a salic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Retic.name: Retic
Retic.description: (from Latin rete, net): having retic properties starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface, but not having albeluvic glossae.

Orthieutric.name: Orthieutric
Orthieutric.description: (from Greek orthos, right): having: � in Histosols, a pHwater ? 5.5 throughout in the organic material within 100 cm of the soil surface, � in other soils, an effective base saturation [exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na) / exchangeable(Ca + Mg + K + Na + Al); exchangeable bases by 1 M NH4OAc (pH 7), exchangeable Al by 1 M KCl (unbuffered)] of ? 50% throughout between 20 and 100 cm from the mineral soil surface.

Ochric.name: Ochric
Ochric.description: (from Greek ochros, pale): having ? 0.2 % soil organic carbon (weighted average) in the layer from the mineral soil surface to a depth of 10 cm from the mineral soil surface; and not having a mollic or umbric horizon and not fulfilling the set of criteria of the Humic qualifier.

Garbic.name: Garbic
Garbic.description: (from English garbage): having a layer ? 20 cm thick, within ? 100 cm of the soil surface, with ? 20% (by volume, weighted average) artefacts containing ? 35% (by volume) organic waste (in Technosols only) (2).

Thionic.name: Thionic
Thionic.description: (from Greek theion, sulfur): having a thionic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (2).

Gypsiric.name: Gypsiric
Gypsiric.description: (from Greek gypsos, gypsum): having gypsiric material throughout between 20 and 100 cm from the soil surface or between 20 cm and continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer, whichever is shallower; and not having a gypsic or petrogypsic horizon starting ? 100 cm from the soil surface (4).

Relocatic.name: Relocatic
Relocatic.description: (from Latin re, again, and locatus, put): being in situ remodelled by human activity to a depth of ? 100 cm (e.g. by deep ploughing, refilling soil pits or levelling land) and no horizon development after remodelling throughout, at least between 20 cm and 100 cm from the soil surface or between the lower limit of any plough layer, > 20 cm thick, and 100 cm from the soil surface (in Technosols, Relocatic is redundant, except in combination with the Ekranic or Linic qualifier); a destroyed diagnostic subsurface horizon may be added with a hyphen, e.g. Spodi-Relocatic, Spodi-Epirelocatic (4: Epi- only).

Mawic.name: Mawic
Mawic.description: (from Kiswahili mawe, stones): having a layer of coarse fragments, the interstices of which are filled with organic material, and that is directly overlain by organic material (in Histosols only) (1: Epi- and Endo- only; referring to the upper limit of the layer of coarse fragments).

Hypersideralic.name: Hypersideralic
Hypersideralic.description: (from Greek hyper, over): having within ? 100 cm of the soil surface a layer that has sideralic properties and a CEC (by 1 M NH4OAc, pH 7) of < 16 cmolc kg-1 clay (2).

Thixotropic.name: Thixotropic
Thixotropic.description:
(from Greek thixis, contact, and Greek tropae, reversion): having
in some layer within ? 50 cm of the soil surface, material that changes, under
pressure or by rubbing, from a plastic solid into a liquefied stage and back into the
solid condition.

Hyperskeletic.name: Hyperskeletic
Hyperskeletic.description: (from Greek hyper, over, and skeletos, dried out): having < 20% (by volume) fine earth, averaged over a depth of 75 cm from the soil surface or to continuous rock, technic hard material or a cemented or indurated layer starting >25 cm from the soil surface, whichever is shallower

Urbic.name: Urbic
Urbic.description: (from Latin urbs, city): having a layer ? 20 cm thick, within ? 100 cm of the soil surface, with ? 20% (by volume, weighted average) artefacts containing ? 35% (by volume) rubble and refuse of human settlements (in Technosols only) (2).

Thapto.name: Thapto
Thapto.description: (from Greek thaptein, to bury) specifier can be used to construct optional or additional subqualifiers. If used with a principal qualifier, the Thapto- subqualifier must shift to the supplementary qualifiers. The Thapto- subqualifiers are placed after the supplementary qualifiers that are listed for the respective RSG and after any Bathy- subqualifier.

Amphi.name: Amphi
Amphi.description: (from Greek amphi, around): the horizon or layer starts > 0 and < 50 cm of the (mineral) soil surface and has its lower limit > 50 and < 100 cm of the (mineral) soil surface; and no such horizon or layer occurs < 1 cm of the (mineral) soil surface; and no such horizon or layer occurs between 99 and 100 cm of the (mineral) soil surface.

Kato.name: Kato
Kato.description: (from Greek kato, downwards): the horizon or layer starts > 0 and < 50 cm of the (mineral) soil surface, and has its lower limit ? 100 cm of the (mineral) soil surface; and no such horizon or layer occurs < 1 cm of the (mineral) soil surface.

Ano.name: Ano
Ano.description: (from Greek ano, upwards): the horizon or layer starts at the (mineral) soil surface, and has its lower limit > 50 and < 100 cm of the (mineral) soil surface; and no such horizon or layer occurs between 99 and 100 cm of the (mineral) soil surface.

Endo.name: Endo
Endo.description: (from Greek endon, inside): the characteristic is present somewhere > 50 and ? 100 cm from the (mineral) soil surface and is absent ? 50 cm from the (mineral) soil surface.

Supra.name: Supra
Supra.description: (from Latin supra, above) specifier can be constructed to describe the soil material above, if the thickness or depth requirements of a qualifier or of its respective diagnostics are not fulfilled, but all other criteria are fulfilled throughout in the soil material above (e.g. Ekranic Technosol (Suprafolic)). If the Supra- specifier is used, the Epi- specifier is not used.

Bathy.name: Bathy
Bathy.description:
(from Greek bathys, deep) specifier
can be used to construct an additional subqualifier. The Bathy- subqualifier
extends to a greater depth than specified for the qualifier. If the Endo- specifier
cannot be added to a qualifier, the Bathy- specifier cannot be used either (e.g.
Alcalic: neither Endo-, nor Bathy-). If used with a principal qualifier, the
Bathy- subqualifier must shift to the supplementary qualifiers. The Bathysubqualifiers are placed after the supplementary qualifiers that are listed for the
respective RSG. With the Bathy- specifier, qualifiers that are not even in the list
for the particular RSG (see Chapter 4) can be added, for example Albic Arenosol
(Bathylixic). If it comprises buried layers, Bathy- is only allowed in combination
with the Thapto- specifier, e.g. Bathythaptovertic (see the Thapto- specifier,
below, and �2.5 Buried soils�, below).

Panto.name: Panto
Panto.description: (from Greek pan, all): the horizon or layer starts at the (mineral) soil surface and has its lower limit ? 100 cm of the (mineral) soil surface.

Epi.name: Epi
Epi.description: (from Greek epi, over): the characteristic is present somewhere ? 50 cm from the (mineral) soil surface and is absent > 50 and ? 100 cm from the (mineral) soil surface.
